history.content:
Hey there, 


If you're interested in UC Berkeley's EECS/CS programs, you should meet with our grad advisers in 205 Cory. If you're interested in other schools (Stanford), you should contact their graduate admissions coordinator(s) for the respective department. Only folks at the institution of interest can be experts on their admission review process and your chances :) 

I know the career center also does some grad school advising but I'm not sure how deep that goes.

children.subject:
yes. You might want to email the appropriate person to set a specific time. 

Graduate Matters

Graduate Admissions Coordinators

Information for Prospective Grad Students

EE – Patrick Hernan
205 Cory Hall, +1 (510) 642-9265
hernan@eecs.berkeley.edu
EE graduate admissions; EE GSI assignments; upper division and graduate CS GSI assignments.

CS - Diana Smith
205 Cory Hall, +1 (510) 642-6285
diana.smith@eecs.berkeley.edu
CS graduate admissions; admissions database; lower division CS GSI assignments; student support.

Masters – Michael Sun
5th Year MS, MS-Only, MEng, and MAS-IC.
205 Cory, +1 (510) 643-8107
msun86@eecs.berkeley.edu
Are the advisers in 205 Cory available over the summer as well?

history.content:
Where can I find more information/talk to someone about graduate school admissions for computer science? I'm most concerned about the GPA requirement (I'm a declared, rising junior with around a 3.2).

I don't have any valuable research experience yet, but I've been pretty involved developing for a startup that works in HCI for a year now (the field I'm interested in), if that counts for anything.

I know I have pretty much no chance at Berkeley's MS program given how selective it is, but I was considering Stanford's. If I raise my GPA (and what would I need to raise it to at least?) and start doing research, would I have a shot? If it's too late, then I probably won't have to study for the GRE and pay attention to my grades as much for the next two years, so I just want to know ahead of time. Any advice/thoughts?
history.subject: Applying to Graduate School
